title: '80 years after the end of World War II, two Europes face each other'
summary: The only certainty is that the international order built after 1945 has collapsed, and the one that must succeed it is yet to be constructed, writes Le Monde columnist Sylvie Kauffmann.

title: The US calls for direct negotiations between Ukraine and Russia
summary: Vice President JD Vance has acknowledged the limits of American mediation as Moscow rejects a full 30-day ceasefire.

title: PSG beats Arsenal 2-1 to reach Champions League final, will now face Inter Milan for title
summary: PSG reached the final of Europe’s elite tournament for the second time in five years. It will take on Inter Milan on May 31 after the three-time champion defeated Barcelona 7-6 on aggregate in one of the greatest semifinals in the competition’s history.

title: Black smoke pours from the Sistine Chapel, indicating that no pope has been elected
summary: After history's most geographically diverse conclave took one round of voting on Wednesday, no winner emerged. The 133 cardinals will retire for the night and return to the Sistine Chapel on Thursday morning to try to find a successor to Pope Francis.

title: Macron meets with Syrian leader al-Sharaa, telling him to protect the rights of 'all people'
summary: Macron had been criticized for hosting the former rebel Islamist chief, but the French president insisted the invitation was essential: '[Sharaa] has put an end to a regime that we condemned and fought against and he is ready to make commitments.'

title: French interior minister promises to tighten criteria for naturalizations
summary: Interior Minister Bruno Retailleau instructed prefects to tighten their criteria when examining requests to obtain French citizenship.

title: US Federal Reserve announces a pause in rate cuts and warns of risk of inflation and unemployment
summary: In a likely reference to President Trump's tariff rollout, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said there was a 'great deal of uncertainty about (...) where tariff policies are going to settle out.' Analysts warn that the Trump administration's actions will likely slow growth − at least in the short run.

title: Putin's order for three-day truce with Ukraine takes effect
summary: 'The ceasefire ... on the 80th anniversary of the Great Victory, has begun,' Russia's state RIA news agency reported.

title: Emmanuel Macron and Friedrich Merz: A 'friendship' that doesn't erase fundamental differences
summary: The new German chancellor was welcomed at the Elysée Palace by Emmanuel Macron on Wednesday for his first foreign trip. Despite friendly words and a desire to revive Franco-German cooperation, the two leaders expressed positions that traditionally reflect those of their respective countries, whether it be in defense, trade or public spending.

title: War in Ukraine: 'This conflict will last another 10 years'
summary: In Zaporizhzhia, a frontline city in southern Ukraine, soldiers and civilians are in despair. Exhausted, the military is losing motivation.

title: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa, weakened by sectarian violence, looks to rebuild ties with France
summary: The former jihadist, seeking to distance himself from his past, is set to meet Emmanuel Macron on Wednesday, May 7. He aims to restore ties between Paris and Damascus, severed in 2012 following Bashar al-Assad's bloody repression of the Syrian Spring.

title: The Trump administration is taking aim at academic journals
summary: Several American journals have received probing letters from the federal prosecutor of the District of Columbia, accusing them of bias in scientific debates. Two federally funded journals have suspended the acceptance of new research articles.

title: Merz supports easing EU fiscal rules to boost defense spending
summary: EU members are bound by spending rules obliging them to keep the public deficit below 3% of economic output and debt at 60% of GDP. But the EU can suspend the rules in exceptional circumstances and crises, as it did during the coronavirus pandemic when states had to prop up their embattled economies.

title: Le Pen sees billionaire's hand behind opinion poll that sidelined her
summary: A survey commissioned by a think tank linked to conservative billionaire Pierre-Edouard Stérin tested Jordan Bardella as the far right's presidential candidate. Marine Le Pen, who still hopes to run, described it as a political manipulation.

title: India bombs Pakistan, which denounces 'an act of war'
summary: The Indian army said it attacked 'terrorist infrastructure' after an April 22 terrorist attack in India's Kashmir region. Pakistan's army claimed to have shot down five Indian aircraft in retaliation, including three Rafales.

title: Thirteen cardinals likely to play a key role during the conclave
summary: Among the 133 cardinal electors gathered at the Vatican to choose Francis's successor, a few key figures stand out. Here's a closer look at them.

title: Duel with Trump has strengthened Xi, at home and abroad
summary: The trade war started by Donald Trump has allowed China to shift the blame for its economic slowdown onto Washington and position itself as a more responsible and predictable power.

title: Canada's new prime minister reaffirms his country's sovereignty on trip to Washington
summary: Mark Carney's first meeting with Donald Trump on Tuesday provided an opportunity to assert that his country 'is not for sale' in response to the threats of annexation alluded to in recent months by his American host.

title: 'Conclave': Is the film faithful to reality?
summary: Edward Berger's thriller portrays a relentless and twist-filled campaign to elect the new pope, with some deviations from the practices and rules of conclaves.

title: Drone strike targets Port Sudan naval base as UN warns of 'major escalation'
summary: Port Sudan is the main entry point for humanitarian aid into Sudan. A spokesman for UN chief Antonio Guterres said the drone strikes 'could lead to large-scale civilian casualties and further destruction of critical infrastructure.' The UN has also warned of more 'human suffering in what is already the world's largest humanitarian crisis.'

title: North Korea fires flurry of short-range ballistic missiles into the Sea of Japan
summary: The launch − the nuclear-armed North's first missile test since March − comes a week after Kim Jong Un's test-firing of a new warship weapons system. Experts warn that the North may be testing weapons for export to Russia for use against Ukraine.

title: Perrier, in a new blow, ordered to remove water filters
summary: French authorities have ordered Nestlé Waters to stop filtering its Perrier and have forbidden the brand from using the description 'natural mineral water.' In a statement, Nestlé says it is 'determined to seek solutions.'

title: Joseph Nye, the political scientist who coined the term 'soft power,' has died at 88
summary: The influential US policymaker and neo-liberal thinker developed the term to signify nations that gain dominance through attractiveness. By winning people over through values and culture, soft power 'co-opts people rather than coerces them.' President Trump has sharply reduced US soft power since returning to office in January.

title: Benedict, Francis, Paul and others: How do popes choose their names?
summary: While speculation mounts over the identity of the next pope, equally intriguing is the name he will choose, as it may offer an early indication of the direction he wishes to steer his pontificate.

title: In Peru, criminal groups target gold mines
summary: 13 miners were found dead on Sunday at the bottom of a gallery in a region overwhelmed by the explosion of illegal gold mining activity, as the country plunges further into violence.

title: India and Pakistan trade fire after deadly escalation
summary: At least 43 deaths have been reported from both sides of the border after the worst violence between the two countries in decades.

title: Flag bearers: Young custodians of France's history
summary: Photojournalist Guillaume Herbaut went to meet a new generation of flag bearers stepping in for veterans during commemoration ceremonies. His gentle and luminous portraits depict adolescents from diverse backgrounds, united by a shared sense of citizenship.

title: Olivier Christin, historian: 'The conclave is where political modernity was invented'
summary: As the assembly of cardinals gathers in Rome starting May 7 to choose the successor to Pope Francis, the specialist of Catholicism speaks in an interview with Le Monde about the roots of our contemporary fascination with this election that has neither candidates nor a campaign.

title: How France and Europe are planning to attract foreign researchers in the Trump era
summary: On Monday, Emmanuel Macron and Ursula von der Leyen announced investments of €100 million for France and €500 million for Europe to make 'Europe an attractive hub' for foreign researchers, eliciting mixed reactions within the academic community.

title: Military operation in Pakistan reveals weaknesses of India's air force
summary: New Delhi has begun to acknowledge the loss of several fighter jets during 'Operation Sindoor.' Military experts suggest that at least one Rafale may be among the destroyed aircraft. This would mark the first loss in combat for the French aircraft.

title: Bertrand Badie, political scientist: 'Since 1945, we have never actually achieved a genuine peace treaty'
summary: The international relations specialist tells Le Monde that the world order established by the Allies 80 years ago has unraveled, with diplomacy at a standstill.

title: Dozens arrested, three hurt by car in Paris after PSG's win to reach Champions League final
summary: Three people were injured when a car crashed into them near the capital's iconic Champs-Elysées avenue as PSG fans celebrated, police said.

title: French diplomat Pierre Vimont: 'Putin wants to take down the world order as it has existed since 1945'
summary: Europe is likely to experience prolonged instability, even if a ceasefire is reached in Ukraine, explains the diplomat in an interview with Le Monde, on the occasion of the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II.

title: Israeli forces close UN schools in annexed east Jerusalem
summary: The United Nations confirmed three schools were closed in the city's Shuafat refugee camp.

title: Lithuania's parliament votes to withdraw from landmines treaty
summary: Latvian lawmakers were the first to vote to quit the treaty last month. Finland also said in April that it planned to withdraw from the treaty amid rising tensions with neighboring Russia.

title: Family of feminicide victim sues French state for 'gross negligence'
summary: Nathalie Debaillie, 47, reported her former partner Jérôme Tonneau to the police four times. Believing that the police's inaction proved fatal to her, her brother, her two children, and the children's father have sued the state for their inaction.

title: Melting sea ice alters color of Arctic and Antarctic oceans
summary: Without an ice layer on the ocean's surface, the light penetrating the waters changes, affecting the type of algae and plankton developing there. A study published in 'Nature' warns of a chain reaction of consequences.

title: Hitler's last 10 days
summary: Secluded in his Berlin bunker since late March 1945, the Führer continued the war until April 22, when, for the first time, he conceded defeat. Adolf Hitler committed suicide eight days later, on April 30.

title: Trump announces US-UK trade agreement
summary: Donald Trump, who had spoken of a 'full and comprehensive' trade agreement, is due to hold a press conference on Thursday to clarify the details. Prime Minister Keir Starmer is also set to speak on the deal.

title: Papal Conclave: Second day of black smoke, cardinals to vote for new pope again
summary: If Thursday afternoon's rounds of voting fail to produce a two-thirds majority, black smoke will billow from the chimney at the Vatican again, at around 7 pm. It will be white if a new pope is elected.

title: Cardinals have elected the next pope
summary: The 133 cardinals picked a successor to Pope Francis on the second day of voting.

title: European media praises PSG: 'They have won so many admirers across the continent'
summary: The Paris team's performance in defeating Arsenal in the Champions League semi-finals on Wednesday was lauded the press, highlighting a change in the club's direction pushed by coach Luis Enrique.

title: 'Inheritance is an injustice': Why a 33-year-old redistributed €27 million
summary: After the death of her grandmother, Marlene Engelhorn, the descendant of the founder of the German chemical and pharmaceutical companies BASF inherited nearly €27 million. An advocate for taxing the wealthy, she donated 92% of that sum to charities.
